author: By Oscar Lopez
title: In Widening Crackdown, Renowned Journalist Arrested in Guatemala
description: José Rubén Zamora, an award-winning journalist and president of the elPeriódico newspaper, was arrested at his home in Guatemala City.
content: In another sign of growing political repression in Guatemala, the authorities have arrested an award-winning journalist who was critical of the government and raided the offices of the newspaper he founded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Francis Calls Abuse of Indigenous People in Canada a ‘Genocide’
description: The pope reinforced his denunciation of the abuse committed by Roman Catholic-run schools in the country. He also acknowledged that his advancing age might force him to travel less in future.
content: ABOARD THE PAPAL PLANE — Pope Francis has called the devastation visited on generations of Indigenous people in Canada by European colonizers — carried out with the blessing of the Roman Catholic Church — a “genocide” as he returned to Rome after a six-day trip to the North American country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Language Evolves Right Before Our Ears. It’s Very ‘Satisfying.’
description: How pickleball and A.S.M.R. may have helped the youngs refine our language forward.
content: Recently, my daughters and I were walking by some people playing pickleball. If you’re not familiar, the game involves a plastic ball being thwacked crisply back and forth, the sound being somewhere between the pop of Ping-Pong and the whop of a smacked Wiffle ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Gang Leaders Convicted in Shocking Murder of Boy Dragged From Bronx Deli
description: Mistaken for a gang member, Lesandro Guzman-Feliz, 15, was hacked to death with knives and a machete in a killing, captured on video, that horrified the city.
content: Two top leaders of the Trinitarios gang were found guilty of murder on Friday for ordering a deadly attack on a 15-year-old boy who was dragged out of a Bronx deli four years ago and hacked to death with knives and a machete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: As Ukraine defends in the east and south, a U.S. official says Russia’s war effort is failing.
description: A senior U.S. Defense Department official said there was growing evidence that steep Russian losses had left some units ill-prepared to fight.
content: The Ukrainian military repelled attempted Russian advances in eastern Ukraine and pounded critical Russian logistical hubs overnight into Saturday as Russia continued to bombard towns and cities along the 400-mile front line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Prince Charles’s Charity Accepted Millions From Family of Osama bin Laden
description: Clarence House confirmed that the terrorist’s brothers donated money to the royal charity, but denied reports that the prince had personally brokered the deal or made the decision to accept it.
content: LONDON — Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, faced new scrutiny over the financing of his charities on Saturday after a report found that one organization had accepted a donation of 1 million pounds ($1.21 million) from the family of Osama bin Laden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Mary Alice, Tony Winner for Her Role in ‘Fences,’ Dies at 85
description: A former Chicago schoolteacher, she appeared on TV in ‘A Different World’ and ‘I’ll Fly Away,’ winning an Emmy in 1993.
content: Mary Alice, an Emmy- and Tony-award winning actress who brought a delicate grace and a quiet dignity to her roles in Hollywood blockbusters (“The Matrix Revolutions”), television sitcoms (“A Different World”) and Broadway plays (“Fences”), died on Wednesday in her home in Manhattan. She was 85, according to the New York City Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Eavesdropping, Worms and Outrageous Fortune
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Keep It Together
description: Lance Enfinger debuts with a sharp Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I need an adjective that means tough yet breezy for puzzles like this, Lance Enfinger’s first Times construction. Brisk, maybe? Or bracing? At first glance, it looks like a steep, uphill battle, but if you get a longer entry or two, you can build some momentum. It’s enjoyable, and there are some excellent touches — interrelated trivia, a couple of great terms and a cetacean idiom that was new to me. I’m also a sucker for the triple span, and this one is well done. (Like a nice filet mignon! Just kidding.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Andre Paultre
title: Gangs Advance on the Seat of Haitian Government Power: ‘Haitians Are Hostages’
description: Over 470 people have been killed, injured or are missing in recent violence, according to the U.N., as gangs expand their control and threaten the presidential palace.
content: Gangs are increasing their chokehold on Haiti’s capital, using bulldozers to raze entire neighborhoods, overwhelming poorly armed police and taking their violence to within blocks of the seat of government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Calls for Investigation Into Prisoner Deaths as Outrage Grows
description: Ukrainian authorities gathered evidence that they said showed Russia had orchestrated an explosion that killed at least 50 of their soldiers.
content: As global outrage grew over an explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners held at a Russian detention camp, Ukrainian authorities called for an international investigation on Saturday while marshaling evidence that they said would prove that Russia had orchestrated what they described as a “terrorist attack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Using Fiction to Summon the Glittering, Golden Age of Hollywood
description: Anthony Marra’s “Mercury Pictures Presents,” his long-awaited second novel, is a homage to the movies and to his immigrant family.
content: After a funeral on Long Island not too long ago, the author Anthony Marra and his family gathered somberly at the grave site for the burial. But there was a moment of unexpected slapstick when an older relative began to fret about the graveyard’s confusing layout. Suddenly she yelled in a thick New York accent: “How the hell do I get out of here?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Not Just Any Bag
description: A New York company, Anybag, finds an elegant way to turn plastic bag waste into a functional tote. Miranda Kerr, Adidas and Ralph Lauren are fans.
content: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: All of Aaron Judge’s Homers, From 1 to 42
description: Judge, the slugging Yankee outfielder, is having an incredible year. We are tracking his pursuit of other Yankees greats.
content: In the second inning of an afternoon game at Yankee Stadium, Aaron Judge got a 95-mile-per-hour fastball from Jonathan Heasley of the Kansas City Royals and muscled it just over the wall in right for a home run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: I Would Have Liked Childhood More Without the Pressure to Grow Up
description: Let’s not make being a kid harder than it already is.
content: If you asked me what I wanted to be when I was a kid, I probably would have told you an archaeologist, or a ballerina, or ideally both, simultaneously. But in reality, what I wanted to be most was an adult. I wanted to be 35. Or 22, which, when you’re 10, is basically the same thing. Anything, absolutely anything, other than a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Wonderfully Mundane Joys of Summer
description: Kids getting to be kids again.
content: A few weeks ago, The Wall Street Journal had a feature about parents who were splurging on summer fun for their kids — expensive birthday parties, all-out road trips — in part to make up for the joy lost during the early days of the Covid pandemic. It’s an understandable urge. Our kids missed out on a lot over the past few years; why not spoil them if we’re able to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Trump Backs Tudor Dixon in Michigan’s Chaotic G.O.P. Governor Primary
description: The winner of the Aug. 2 primary, which has been in turmoil since May, will take on Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, this fall.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Tudor Dixon in Michigan’s Republican primary for governor, giving Ms. Dixon, a former media personality, a boost as the crowded field heads into the final weekend of campaigning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Soon Is Too Soon to Ask My Landlord About a Rent Increase?
description: Simply asking a landlord about how much the rent will go up shouldn’t change the landlord’s calculations — the decision has likely already been made.
content: Q: For nine years, my husband and I have rented a market-rate apartment on the Upper West Side. The building recently changed ownership, and during the transition apartments were intentionally left vacant until the new owners took over. Now that new management is running the building, comparable units to ours are renting at much higher rents than what we pay. Our lease comes up for renewal in October and we are concerned about the potential increase we could face. Should we ask the landlord about the renewal terms early, or is it better to wait? How might we approach the conversation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Heavy Rain Causes Deadly Flooding Across Iran
description: The monsoon-like rains, unusual for the typical dry season in the region, have killed more than 50 people, caused heavy damage and shut down major roadways.
content: Heavy rains in Iran that began Wednesday have set off flash floods and landslides in 21 of the country’s 31 provinces, killing at least 53 people, heavily damaging hundreds of villages, cutting off access to major roads and forcing the evacuation of an ancient city, officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Adam Zagoria
title: What’s Next for LeBron James Jr.?
description: Coaches recruiting the high school point guard known as Bronny will have a lot to navigate, including his famous father’s ties to Nike, ESPN and the state of Ohio.
content: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — As LeBron James sat on a folding chair in the corner of a recreation-center basketball court last week, he often appeared to be in a state of agita.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Followers of Iraqi Cleric Occupy Parliament Again, Demanding Reforms
description: Unable to form a government 10 months after elections, Iraq has been roiled by the street protests of the nationalist cleric Moktada al-Sadr, who withdrew from the government but again seeks to influence it.
content: BASRA, Iraq — Iraqi protesters loyal to the nationalist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr thronged Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone for the second time in a week on Saturday to prevent the formation of a new government. They scaled concrete barriers and pushed past security forces to get into the Iraqi Parliament, filling the empty seats of representatives and shouting their support for Mr. Sadr: “Son of Mohammed, take us wherever you want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Ali Watkins
title: How Did a Two-Time Killer Get Out to Be Charged Again at Age 83?
description: Marceline Harvey is accused of dismembering a woman in Brooklyn. Her life was defined by a tormented relationship with women and herself — and a simmering anger.
content: The person before the parole panel in June 2019 was tall and slim, in far better shape than 81 years of life might have suggested. Mild and polite, the supplicant seemed nothing like the murderer who had spent decades in prison, first for shooting a girlfriend dead in 1963, and then for stabbing another in 1985, stuffing her corpse into a bag and leaving it in Central Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Why? Well, Why Not?
description: Jesse Goldberg’s puzzle will really make you wonder.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jesse Goldberg is a software engineer in San Francisco. This is his third crossword for The Times (and his second Sunday puzzle — his first, from almost exactly a year ago, was lovely and pulled quotations from a famous French kitchen, if you missed it). Many solvers will be familiar with this puzzle-loving constructor’s daily routine: Solve Wordle, check Wordlebot, play Spelling Bee, solve the crossword, in that order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Gottlieb
title: Monkeypox Is About to Become the Next Public Health Failure
description: The outbreak doesn’t bode well for America’s response to future pathogens.
content: When about 100 cases of ‌‌monkeypox had been confirmed or suspected in Europe‌ in May, it was clear the virus was spreading outside the areas where it was previously seen‌‌. Some on social media ‌‌suggested it might already be ‌spreading rapidly in communities in Europe and the ‌United States. These reports should have been a code red for federal infectious disease response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Gets F.A.A. Go-Ahead for Plan to Resume Deliveries of 787 Dreamliner
description: The planes were grounded for more than a year over quality concerns. The agency will still inspect them before they are handed over to customers.
content: Federal regulators on Friday cleared the way for Boeing to restart deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner, which were paused more than a year ago because of quality concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Pac-12 Commissioner Keeps It Professional, but Pointed, After Defections
description: George Kliavkoff, the Pac-12 commissioner, said the move by U.C.L.A. and U.S.C. to leave the conference for the Big Ten was a money grab that sold out athletes.
content: LOS ANGELES — When the Pac-12 Conference’s schools congregated Friday at a downtown theater for the summer ritual of football media day — and yes, all the coaches were invited — it carried the air of an awkward family reunion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Vessels await word that they can carry the first grain shipments out of Ukraine.
description: ODESA, Ukraine — The first shipments of grain since the beginning of the war in Ukraine have been loaded onto freighters at Ukrainian ports on the Black Sea, getting ready for their first voyages in more than five months.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — The first shipments of grain since the beginning of the war in Ukraine have been loaded onto freighters at Ukrainian ports on the Black Sea, getting ready for their first voyages in more than five months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Savors Much-Needed Victories. But Will the Highs Overshadow the Lows?
description: With the midterm elections around the corner, the challenge for President Biden is to make sure his latest successes resonate with Americans who remain deeply skeptical about the future.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his top advisers have tried for months to press forward amid a seemingly endless drumbeat of dispiriting news: rising inflation, high gas prices, a crumbling agenda, a dangerously slowing economy and a plummeting approval rating, even among Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
title: A Polish Priest’s War Against Abortion Focuses on Helping Single Mothers
description: The Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk sees little effect on women’s decisions whether to have a child from a 29-year abortion ban. What may matter more is support for women who choose to have a child.
content: SZCZECIN, Poland — Abortion has been banned in Poland for 29 years, but that has done little to prevent women from finding access to the procedure, leaving the Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk a busy man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: G.O.P. Feuding and Chaos Endanger the Party’s Chances in Michigan
description: A handwritten letter from Betsy DeVos, last seen trying to remove Donald Trump from office, elicited an 11th-hour endorsement. But is that enough to make peace among Michigan’s warring Republicans?
content: PONTIAC, Mich. — “Dear Mr. President,” the letter began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Best Extracurricular May Be an After-School Job
description: Personally, I learned more working outside school than I did in the classroom.
content: Lots of American teenagers need to work after school to help support their families. But there’s a case to be made that those who don’t need to work should get a job anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Debris From Uncontrolled Chinese Rocket Falls Over Southeast Asian Seas
description: Space watchers had tracked the 23-ton rocket stage’s path in Earth orbit this week because of the slight possibility that it could come down over a populated area.
content: Debris from a large Chinese rocket re-entered Earth’s atmosphere over the Indian Ocean at 12:45 p.m. Eastern time, according to the U.S. Space Command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: White House Communications Director, Set to Depart, Decides to Stay
description: Kate Bedingfield, who announced this month that she was stepping down, abruptly changed her mind and said on Friday that she had decided to remain at the White House.
content: WASHINGTON — At this point in an administration, with the president’s poll numbers in the tank and a daunting midterm election on the horizon, the usual staff news around the White House is a roster of who is leaving. But in an unusual twist, the news on Friday was who is not leaving after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tricia Fulks Kelley, Rick Rojas and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘We Keep Getting Hit’: Flooded Kentucky Grows Weary After Another Natural Disaster
description: A series of catastrophes has struck communities that were already struggling, raising fears that rebuilding will be arduous and require substantial outside help.
content: HAZARD, Ky. — Firefighters and National Guard crews have swarmed into eastern Kentucky after days of deadly flooding, rescuing by the hundreds people who found themselves trapped in the perilous water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: You Want to Clean Up the House? Same Here
description: How to improve the House of Representatives.
content: A lot of you responded quite strongly to last week’s newsletter on defanging the Senate of most of its power. Not a negative response, necessarily — you just had a lot of ideas! And as it happens, I agree with many of those ideas. Perhaps the most common one is related less to the Senate than to the House of Representatives. Many of you were adamant that if the goal is to bring the locus of policymaking back to the House, then the House, too, must be more democratic than it is, and that part of making the House more democratic is ending partisan gerrymandering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz
title: How the Kremlin Is Forcing Ukrainians to Adopt Russian Life
description: In Russian-occupied regions in Ukraine, local leaders are forcing civilians to accept Russian rule. Next come sham elections that would formalize Vladimir V. Putin’s claim that they are Russian territories.
content: They have handed out Russian passports, cellphone numbers and set-top boxes for watching Russian television. They have replaced Ukrainian currency with the ruble, rerouted the internet through Russian servers and arrested hundreds who have resisted assimilation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chad Hanson and Michael Dorsey
title: The Case Against Commercial Logging in Wildfire-Prone Forests
description: Logging tends to increase, not decrease, extreme fires.
content: When the Oak fire swept through more than 10,000 acres southwest of Yosemite National Park last weekend, it burned through forests where widespread logging, including commercial thinning, accelerated in recent decades. Much of the forest canopy had been removed, exposing the remaining vegetation to more direct sunlight and creating hotter, drier and windier conditions that favor the spread of flames.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Germans Tiptoe a Path to Energy Conservation
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 30, 2022.
content: “If you think, OK, swapping out the shower head, thawing out the freezer or turning down the heater, none of that makes a difference — you are deceiving yourself. It is an excuse to do nothing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can We Resist the Age of the Algorithm?
description: To resist, our culture needs less Netflix and more Miranda Priestly.
content: I have few stronger opinions about movie characters than my view that Miranda Priestly, the demanding fashion-magazine boss in “The Devil Wears Prada,” is actually the heroine of the movie. Not an uncomplicated heroine, certainly not a nice person. But a figure to be celebrated nonetheless: a demanding, uncompromising aesthete whose decisions ripple through the wider culture, whose idiosyncratic taste can affect the palette of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones Puts Company Behind Infowars Empire Into Bankruptcy
description: The move came as he faces a judgment of as much as $150 million for defaming Sandy Hook families.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Facing a potential $150 million judgment and two more damages trials for defaming the families of people killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting, the conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones on Friday put his Infowars empire into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: A $30 Alarm Can Stop a Silent Killer. Why Many Hotels Don’t Install Them.
description: Three carbon monoxide deaths at a resort in the Bahamas called attention to the dangers of the odorless gas. In the U.S., where it often takes multiple poisonings for hotels to install alarms, a debate about detector policies has been intensifying.
content: He was not the first guest to fall ill in Room 205. Just when Pawel Markowski thought that nothing could shake him more than nearly losing his life to a carbon monoxide leak at a hotel in Catoosa, Okla., his lawyer sent him the Fire Department’s report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Palestinian Flags Aren’t Illegal in Israel. They Still Get Torn Down.
description: Israeli police, lawmakers and settlers are increasingly targeting the flag, which Palestinians say is a broader attack on their identity.
content: JERUSALEM — Amid a sea of Israeli flags at the entrance to the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem’s Old City, Abdullah al-Hajj walked toward a group of far-right Jewish marchers, some of them yelling racist chants, and raised the Palestinian flag above his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Europe’s Race to Secure New Energy Sources Is on a Knife’s Edge
description: A long-term switch to more renewable sources has been overtaken by a short-term scramble to stave off a crisis.
content: As Russia tightens its chokehold on supplies of natural gas, Europe is looking everywhere for energy to keep its economy running. Coal-fired power plants are being revived. Billions are being spent on terminals to bring in liquefied natural gas, much of it from shale fields in Texas. Officials and heads of state are flying to Qatar, Azerbaijan, Norway and Algeria to nail down energy deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 25, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Seeking Relationship, Therapy Required
description: For some singles, a potential partner who isn’t working on their mental health is not an option.
content: Like most daters, Elyse Fox, 32, a model who lives in Brooklyn, is looking for a partner who is kind, attractive, smart and funny. She is hoping he likes to travel, is ready for commitment and communicates well. But she has one nonnegotiable: He must be working on his mental health, preferably in regular therapy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and George Etheredge
title: Retail’s ‘Dark Side’: As Inventory Piles Up, Liquidation Warehouses Are Busy
description: Consumers are buying fewer discretionary goods and returning more. To clear their shelves, retailers are selling to liquidators at steep discounts.
content: PITTSTON, Pa. — Once upon a time, when parents were scrambling to occupy their children during pandemic lockdowns, bicycles were hard to find. But today, in a giant warehouse in northeastern Pennsylvania, there are shiny new Huffys and Schwinns available at big discounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Noah Weiland
title: Biden Tests Positive for Covid Again in ‘Rebound’ Case
description: The president tested positive on Saturday morning and will once again isolate, although his symptoms have not come back, the White House physician said.
content: President Biden tested positive for the coronavirus again on Saturday morning, becoming the latest example of a rebound case after taking the Paxlovid treatment that has otherwise been credited with broadly impressive results in fighting the virus and suppressing its worst effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Got a Climate Bill. Joe Manchin Got Drilling, and More.
description: Along the way to the $369 billion package, the West Virginia senator secured an array of concessions for his state and for the fossil fuel industry.
content: WASHINGTON — In a twist of fate, Congress is suddenly poised to pass the most ambitious climate bill in United States history, largely written by a senator from a coal state who became a millionaire from his family coal business and who has taken more campaign cash from the oil and gas industry than any of his colleagues have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Taylor
title: Banana Yoshimoto Wants You to Feel Again
description: In “Dead-End Memories,” five stories about lonely women who encounter ghosts, infidelities, betrayals — and human connection.
content: The five stories in Banana Yoshimoto’s collection “Dead-End Memories” — first published in Japan in 2003, it is her 11th book to be translated into English — are strange, melancholy and beautiful. At the center of each is a woman negotiating the quiet fallout of personal history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: America Has a Problem and Beyoncé Ain’t It
description: On “Renaissance,” the pop star’s seventh solo album, she finds escape, rebirth, community, pleasure and control in decades of dance music steeped in Black queer bravado.
content: It’s too much, this being alive. Too heavy, too uncertain, too chronically cataclysmic, too bellicose, too unwell, too freighted with a possibility of the perception of error. The word of the last few years — in American activist and academic circles, anyway — has been “precarity.” Which gets at ideas of endangerment, neglect, contingency, risk. Basically: We’re worried. And: We’re worried you’re not worried enough. Like I said: It’s too much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Excitement, Then Ambivalence, For the Pope’s Visit to Quebec
description: Thousands gathered on Wednesday to see Pope Francis ride by the Plains of Abraham park. But a mass the following day was not a big draw.
content: QUEBEC CITY — The smell of cigarette smoke, fruity vape juice and sunscreen might have been a flashback for visitors returning to the sprawling Quebec City park where, two weeks ago, an annual summer music festival drew boisterous crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Ava Sasani
title: In Flood-Stricken Kentucky, the Search for Victims Intensifies
description: As the weather cleared temporarily in the state’s eastern region, rescuers worked with aircraft, boats and vehicles to reach those stranded.
content: The response to some of the worst flooding in Kentucky’s history entered a pivotal phase on Saturday, as the search for victims accelerated over a battered stretch of central Appalachia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs and Text by Tailyr Irvine
title: Powwow Season in Full Bloom
description: From spring to summer, Native American families travel the country to celebrate and compete in competitions  wearing intricate garments assembled across generations.
content: From spring to summer, Native American families travel the country to celebrate and compete in competitions  wearing intricate garments assembled across generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Protesters Breach Iraqi Parliament for Second Time in a Week
description: Iraqi supporters of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr pulled down concrete barriers and packed the Parliament floor, protesting a rival bloc’s efforts to form a new government.
content: Iraqi supporters of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr pulled down concrete barriers and packed the Parliament floor, protesting a rival bloc’s efforts to form a new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Flooding Across Iran Leaves Dozens Dead
description: Days of heavy rain triggered flash floods and landslides across most of Iran’s provinces, marking the nation’s deadliest water-related episode in a decade.
content: Days of heavy rain triggered flash floods and landslides across most of Iran’s provinces, marking the nation’s deadliest water-related episode in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Podcast Recommendations
description: Try out a new podcast or two, courtesy of Morning readers.
content: What makes a good podcast? I’ve been mulling this question over the past few weeks since I asked readers of The Morning to recommend their favorites.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Risks Facing Doctors and Their Pregnant Patients
description: Readers discuss how new abortion laws will affect treatment of miscarriages and life-threatening pregnancies.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 30, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 30, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s health secretary’s suggestion that states bear responsibility for a flawed response to a rise in monkeypox cases incorrectly attributed a comment about the challenges of coordinating a national response to monkeypox. Adriane Casalotti, the chief of public and government affairs for the National Association of County and City Health Officials, spoke about the issues, not Theresa Spinner, a spokeswoman for the group.
source.name: The New York Times
